channel.description: [quote="troubadour, post:19, topic:196"]I'll start again with the packaging, but I think it would be nice to try replacing the popups for whonixcheck and timesync too.[/quote] Yeah. Now that we have a python coder, I am really excited! That would have to be added to https://github.com/Whonix/msgcollector [message notification system developed for Whonix, that can show messages in X as well as in terminal, usable by anyone, not just Whonix, soon]. I package it a bit better soon. Nevertheless, a python GUI could be called from https://github.com/Whonix/msgcollector/blob/master/usr/lib/msgcollector/msgdispatcher. Not required to understand full msgcollector (certainly helpful, but not mandatory for this). When you search that script for zenity, that's the part that would have to be changed. Instead of running zenity with all those arguments, a python script could be called. Also instead of running kdialog (for passive popups) we could also consider using python if that would bring any advantages.

item.title: Whonixcheck, timesync GUI, msgcollector
item.dc:creator: troubadour
item.description:
[quote=“troubadour, post:150, topic:246”]From what I could gather, the problem seems inherent to Qt’s design.
I am working on a hack to implement in msgcollector (basically word wrapping in there) and there is another solution, using a different widget to display the messages (with some limitations), Lastly, If none of those are acceptable, I’ll check if Gtk has the same issue.[/quote]

It seems we are trying to accomplish something original (in the sense that it was never tried before). In order to stay int acceptable limits, we’ll have to accept a compromise. The solution to rewrite a word wrapping function (either in bash in msgcollector or in python in a external function) is ugly and will never manage all the possible situations. The non-documented solutions on stackexchange just mention some improbable hacks in the C++ code in QT.

The first option is in a new branch: https://github.com/troubadoour/msgcollector/tree/textbrowser.

If all the tests results are OK, the window is displayed with a fixed height, not changeable programmatically. For whonixcheck, because the text is too long for the text area, a scroll bar is added. The timesync window is the same height, without scroll bar. The user can resize (expand only) or maximize the dialogs.

If any test does not pass, the height of the window is set at 1/2 screen height (we can change that, but that will determine the minimum height of the window). The scroll bar is shown if needed.

Other options if warning or error:

  • change the background color
  • scroll to the line and highlight the pretty_type (select). If the warning-error is outside the displayed area, it will be shown at the bottom.

We could use any combinations of the options.
